Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports a 4-day conference on "The geometry and topology of 3-manifolds" to be held May 25-28, 2018 at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology on the island of Okinawa in Japan. This conference will bring together a distinguished international group of about 60 participants to discuss recent developments in this area. The participants will be a diverse group of prominent researchers and promising junior mathematicians from Asia, Australia, Western Europe, and North America, with most participants being from Asia and the US. This award will provide funding for ten US based graduate students or recently graduated postdocs to attend the conference.

The study of 3-manifolds from the classical topological viewpoint and its study from the geometric viewpoint have been increasingly overlapping. Among recent well-known results in the area are Perelman's solution of the Geometrization Conjecture (2006) and Agol's solution of the Virtual Haken Conjecture (2012). These results explore the interactions between the geometry and topology of 3-manifolds, but raise even more questions about the nature of these interactions. The conference will be devoted to new work that sheds light on this picture. Topics covered will connect to hyperbolic geometry, algorithmic methods, computational geometry, knot theory, geometric group theory, and new invariants. This workshop will provide a venue for an exchange of ideas between prominent Western topologists and leading researchers from Asia. It will feature approximately 16 speakers presenting recent research progress. Additionally, there will be a public lecture aimed at a general scientific audience.

The conference website is at
https://groups.oist.jp/manifolds/workshop

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported attendance at a 4-day conference on The geometry and topology of 3-manifolds, held from May 25 to May 28, 2017 at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology on the island of Okinawa in Japan. The grant provided funding to allow ten US based graduate students or recently graduated postdocs to travel to the conference.

The topic ot the conference centered on the 3-dimensional topology. The study of 3-manifolds from the classical topological viewpoint and its study from the geometric viewpoint have been increasingly overlapping. Riley's unexpected observations and Thurston's visionary work on the existence of geometric structures on 3-manifolds can been seen as the beginnings of this field. Now, after 40 years of rapid development, major conjectures and questions are still being answered, proved and explored. Among recent well-known results in the area are, for example, Perelman's solution of the Geometrization Conjecture (2006) based on the work of Hamilton and others and  Agol's solution of the Virtual Haken Conjecture (2012) extending work of Sageev, Wise and others. These results explore the interactions between the geometry and topology of 3-manifolds, but raise even more questions about the nature of these interactions. The conference was in part devoted to exciting new work that sheds light on this  picture.

The conference was held successfully, with about 75 participants from around the world. Additional support for the conference was provided by OIST. 

Travel of ten US participants was supported by this grant, for a total of $17,000. Grant administration was provided by the Mathematics Department at UC Davis.

There were in attendance:

  1. 75 participants
  2. 15 grad students
  3. 19 female participants
  4. 9 postdocs

16 speakers delivered research lectures to the 75 participants from around the world. In addition, a public talk was held and many local scientists from other fields attended.
